doc.title: Saipem: Allegro! (Part 6) - Have investors really heard the bullish 2Q25 message?
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Bernstein/Saipem Allegro Part 6 - Have investors really heard the bullish 2Q25 messageSaipem Allegro Part 6 - Have investors reall_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Bernstein

passages.text: We update our Saipem model after the 2Q25 (23 July) results and reiterate our Outperform rating and DCF- based PT of €3.54.

Have investors really heard the bullish 2Q25 message? Three important - and positive - pieces of news were released with Saipem's 2Q25 results on 23- 24 July. 1) First, we acknowledge that the 2Q25 earnings beat (€413m vs BBG consensus of €383m) was of very high quality: the additional c.€144m provision booked in 2Q25 materially reduces the risks of both legacy projects (Thai Oil, Courseulles) and the need for future provisioning - implying potential positive surprises on margins going forward. 2) The publication of the finalised merger agreement (DMA) with Subsea 7 only marginally changes the economics of the deal agreed in the February 2025 MOU, with an additional extraordinary dividend of €105m for Subsea 7's shareholders. 3) The outlook for 2H25 looks very good in our view (higher revenue, higher EBITDA, higher order intake) suggesting further positive surprises in the coming weeks.

FY25 guidance (revenue c.€15bn; EBITDA c.€1.6bn; operating cash flow c.€900m; FCF after lease repayments c.€500m) now looks conservative to us in light of the 1H25 figures: €7,211m; €764m; €842m; c.€600m). And the total execution backlog in 2H25 is €6.7bn, consisting of ABS €4.5bn, Energy Carriers €2.0 and Drilling Offshore €0.2bn. Visibility for 2026 appears particularly good to us (execution backlog in 2026 is €12.9bn; BBG revs cons: €15.7bn; BERN: €14.5bn).

Is Offshore Drilling about to bottom out? We listened carefully to the Transocean (NR) 2Q25 earnings call and were struck by the following statement: "... all projections suggest that we are nearing the end of this temporary slowdown". Saipem expects a low- teens decline in Offshore Drilling revenue in 2H25 as it may return three leased units (Perro Negro 9, Perro Negro 12 and Pioneer

Short- term catalysts for the share in the coming weeks could include: 1) Significant new orders across all geographies, 2) Positive messaging from the company at the September brokers' conferences, and 3) likely better- than- expected 3Q25 results (22 October).
Source: Bloomberg, Bernstein estimates and analysis.
Price Performance, 1YR

See the Disclosure Appendix of this report for required disclosures, analyst certifications and other important information. Alternatively, visit our Global Research Disclosure Website. First Published: 28 Aug 2025 05:02 UTC Completion Date: 27 Aug 2025 17:51 UTC

On 24 July 2025, Saipem and Subsea7 announced that they had entered into a binding merger agreement, which essentially reflects the terms and conditions of the MoU signed on 23 February 2025, thereby putting Saipem and Subsea 7 firmly on track to merge.

- Saipem7 will have revenue of c.21bn (based on the FY24 results, EBITDA \(>E2bn\) , will generate \(>E800m\) in FCF, and will have a combined backlog of \(\sim E43bn\) .- The diversification of the geographical footprints of Saipem and Subsea7 is reflected in the combined backlog, with no single country contributing more than \(15\%\) of total.- On completion, Saipem and Subsea7 shareholders will own \(50\%\) each of the share capital of Saipem7.- Subsea7 shareholders participating in the Proposed Combination will receive 6.688 new Saipem 7 shares for each Subsea7 share held.- Each company is to distribute at least \(300m\) in dividends in 2026. In addition to that, Subsea7 will also distribute a dividend of \(105m\) to its shareholders prior to the completion of the Proposed Combination.- Annual synergies are expected to be approximately \(300m\) on a run-rate basis.- Saipem7 will remain incorporated in Italy and headquartered in Milan, and will have its shares listed on both the Milan and Oslo stock exchanges. However, the offshore businesses (Subsea 7 + Saipem's ABS) will be headquartered in London.

We view this tie- up very positively as the two companies have complementary offers with different key geographies. We view the \(300m\) annual synergies figure as very conservative. One question nonetheless remains: are the two companies' cultures really compatible?

A beat at the EBITDA level. Saipem reported better- than- expected 2Q25 results at the EBITDA level at 413m (+39.1% yoy; BBG cons. 383m; BERN: 382m). Revenue of 3,518m, \(+9.6\%\) yoy, was lower than the BBG cons. (3,736m) and BERN estimates (3,674m).

A miss at the EBIT and net income levels. 2Q25 EBIT of 148m (+12.1%; BBG cons: 179m) and 2Q25 net income of 63m (+3.3%; BBG cons: 696m) were lower than expected. The difference was due to a very high D&A charge of 265m (vs 165m in 2Q24). This high D&A charge is explained by a higher proportion of leased assets within both the Asset Based Services (2Q25 D&A of 182m vs 108m in 2Q24) and Offshore Drilling (2Q25 D&A of 61m vs 40m in 2Q24) segments.

Genuine positive surprises from the ABS and Offshore Drilling segments. 1) Asset Based Services revenue came in at 2,117m, with EBITDA of 288m (a good 13.6% margin) - ahead of the BERN estimates (2,120m/276m/13%). 2) Energy Carriers revenue amounted to 1,326m with EBITDA of 22m - below the BERN estimates (1,365m/25m). 3) The Offshore drilling segment also posted a very good set of 2Q25 results, with revenue of 250m and EBITDA of 103m (41.2% margin) - ahead of BERN estimates (209m/81m).
EXHIBIT 1: **We expected lower FY25 revenue as a result of lower Offshore Drilling revenue in 2H25, while ABS and** **Energy Carrier are expected to support higher EBITDA margin for 2H25**
Source: Bernstein analysis & estimates
EXHIBIT 2: **While we are in line with consensus for 2025, our estimates remain below consensus for 2026-28,** **reflecting our cautious view on ABS pending new orders**
Source: Bernstein analysis & estimates, BBG

Saipem expects higher 2H ABS revenue, EBITDA and EBITDA margin, which raises the probability significantly of further positive surprises given that the 1H beat was achieved despite substantial provisioning. Energy Carriers is also set to improve in 2H as the onshore exposure to zero-margin legacy projects is now contained to <100m.
EXHIBIT 3: ABS and Energy Carriers are both expected to grow in 2H25, while we expect a double-digit revenue contraction for Offshore Drilling given the three fewer units in operation
2025 quarterly P&L (€m)
Source: Company data, Bernstein analysis & estimates
EXHIBIT 4: **Our estimates are in line with Saipem's 2025-28 strategic plan.**
EXHIBIT 5: Cash generation to remain very solid (despite 2026/27 WC outflows)
Source: Company data, Bernstein analysis & estimates

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, LP. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.
Our €3.54 PT is based on a DCF with a \(9.5\%\) WACC, LT growth post 2030 of \(3\%\) and a post- 2030 normalised FCF of €366m.

Downside risks: 1) further still- unidentified project issues within the backlog; 2) extremely low 2025 order intake; 3) rapid decline in drilling offshore revenue and; 4) inability to compete on new energy transition markets.

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI) index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European

insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non-Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp- Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-10 pp- Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon. Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12- month time horizon.
